{{Short description|American musician (1925–2019)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Mac Wiseman | image = Mac Wiseman 2008.jpg | alt = | caption = Wiseman in 2008 | birth_name = Malcolm Bell Wiseman{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/25/obituaries/mac-wiseman-dead.html|title=Mac Wiseman, Bluegrass Star Who Was Much More Than That, Dies at 93|first=Bill|last=Friskics-Warren|date=February 25, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 30, 2019}} | birth_date = {{birth date|1925|05|23}} | birth_place = [[Crimora, Virginia|Crimora]], [[Virginia]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2019|2|24|1925|5|23}} | death_place = [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = Bluegrass, country | occupation = Singer, musician | instrument = Guitar | years_active = 1944–2019 | label = [[Dot Records|Dot]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[RCA Records|RCA]], [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]], [[CMH Records|CMH]], [[Oh Boy Records|Oh Boy]], [[Rural Rhythm Records|Rural Rhythm]], [[Mountain Fever Records|Mountain Fever]] |past_member_of = [[The GrooveGrass Boyz]] }} {{Lead too short|date=July 2022}} '''Malcolm Bell Wiseman''' (May 23, 1925 – February 24, 2019) was an American [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[Country music|country]] singer. ==Early life== He was born on May 23, 1925, in [[Crimora, Virginia]]. He attended school in [[New Hope, Augusta County, Virginia|New Hope, Virginia]], and graduated from high school there in 1943. He had [[polio]] from the age of six months; due to his disabilities, he could not do field work and spent his time in childhood listening to old records. He studied at the [[Shenandoah University|Shenandoah Conservatory]] in [[Dayton, Virginia]], before it moved to [[Winchester, Virginia]], in 1960 and started his career as a disc jockey at [[WSVA|WSVA-AM]] in [[Harrisonburg, Virginia]].{{cite news |last1=Thanki |first1=Juli |title=Country, bluegrass great Wiseman, dead at 93 |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2019/02/24/mac-wiseman-dies-bluegrass-country-flatt-scruggs-foggy-mountain-boys-bill-monroe/656636002/ |access-date=25 February 2019 |issue=56 |publisher=The Tennessean |date=February 25, 2019 |volume=115 |page=1A}} ==Music career== His musical career began as upright bass player in the Cumberland Mountain Folks, the band of country singer [[Molly O'Day (singer)|Molly O'Day]]. When [[Lester Flatt]] and [[Earl Scruggs]] left Bill Monroe's band, Wiseman became the guitarist for their new band, the [[Foggy Mountain Boys]]. Later he played with [[Bill Monroe]]'s Bluegrass Boys. In 1951, his first solo single, "'Tis Sweet to Be Remembered", was released. According to ''Rolling Stone'' this song "catapulted him to solo stardom". In 1958, Wiseman helped co-found the [[Country Music Association]] (CMA) to save the popularity of country music from rock & roll, and served as the organization's first secretary, eventually becoming its last living co-founder. From 1966 to 1970, Wiseman served as director of the ''[[WWVA Jamboree]]''. In 1986 he co-founded the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (IBMA) which was another influential bluegrass music body. Wiseman was referred to by a [[disc jockey]] as "The Voice with a Heart", a title which became popular among his fans. He was popular for his interpretations of songs on [[Dot Records]] such as "Shackles and Chains", "I'll Be All Smiles Tonight", "Jimmy Brown the Newsboy", and "Love Letters in the Sand".{{cite news |last1=Gill |first1=Joey |title=Bluegrass musician Mac Wiseman dies at 93 |url=https://www.wsmv.com/news/bluegrass-musician-mac-wiseman-dies-at/article_2716c8ca-3875-11e9-928c-47bf0b4217ec.html |access-date=February 25, 2019 |work=WSMV Nashville |date=February 24, 2019 |language=en}} In 2014, he released an album of songs inspired by his mother's handwritten notebooks of songs she heard on the radio when Wiseman was a child: ''Songs From My Mother's Hand''.{{cite web| url=http://www.wrinkledrecords.com/american-treasure-bluegrass-pioneer-country-music-hall-of-famer-mac-wiseman-releases-masterwork-album-of-folk-songs-from-his-childhood-available-worldwide-september-23-on-wrinkled-records/ |title=American Treasure, Bluegrass Pioneer, Country Music Hall of Famer Mac Wiseman releases masterwork album of folk songs from his childhood |publisher=Wrinkled Records |date=July 11, 2014 |access-date=August 15, 2014}} He died in [[Nashville]] on February 24, 2019, at the age of 93.{{cite magazine |last=Moore |first=Bobby |title=Mac Wiseman, Bluegrass Icon, Dead at 93 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/mac-wiseman-bluegrass-country-music-dead-obituary-799481/ |access-date=February 25, 2019 |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=February 25, 2019}} The cause of death was kidney failure. {{blockquote|Mac Wiseman recorded splendid and often groundbreaking music for more than seventy years, remaining relevant and productive even in his nineties. He was a titan of bluegrass music's first generation, though bluegrass never defined him. He helped found the CMA, he headed Dot Records' country division, and he recorded with everyone from big band legend Woody Herman to Rock and Roll Hall of Famer Duane Eddy to Americana poet laureate John Prine. |author=Kyle Young, CEO, Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|source=}} ==Awards and honors== In 1993 he was inducted into the [[International Bluegrass Music Hall of Honor]].{{cite web |title=Mac Wiseman |url=https://www.bluegrasshall.org/inductees/mac-wiseman/ |website=Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame & Museum |date=October 23, 2018 |access-date=February 25, 2019}} Wiseman was a recipient of a 2008 [[National Heritage Fellowship]] awarded by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], which is the United States' highest honor in the folk and traditional arts.{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/year/2008 |title=NEA National Heritage Fellowships 2008 |author= |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=National Endowment for the Arts |access-date=January 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200815022933/https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/year/2008 |archive-date=August 15, 2020 |url-status=dead}} In 2014 he became part of the ''Veteran Era'' category of the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]], as "an artist who achieved national prominence more than 45 years ago".{{cite web| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/country-hall-of-fame-taps-ronnie-milsap-mac-wiseman-hank-cochran-20140422 |title=Country Hall of Fame Taps Ronnie Milsap, Mac Wiseman, Hank Cochran |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=April 22, 2014 |access-date=April 22, 2014}} ==Selected discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;
